newsitem.title: USA: Technology shares in US up on improving sentiment.
newsitem.headline: Technology shares in US up on improving sentiment.

text.p: Technology stocks rallied on Friday on signs Wall Street's outlook on the sector is improving after months of disfavor.
One standout Friday was International Business Machines Corp, which jumped 4-1/4 to 121-1/2 after Merrill Lynch raised its near-term rating to a strong buy from accumulate.
SoundView Financial Group President and Market Strategist James Townsend said technology stocks as a group are poised to outperform the broad market once again.

Since the marketwide sell-off in July, tech stocks have lagged the broad market and the tech-laden Nasdaq Composite remains well below its peak even as the resurgent Dow has rebounded, setting an intraday record early today.

Townsend, who raised his near-term weighting on the sector to overweight from average, said he expects the group as measured by the firm's SoundView index to rally by 30-40 percent over the next four to five months.

"Generally speaking, technology as a group has underperformed not only for the last few months, but actually from September 13, 1995, so one can argue there's been a long-term period of relative underperformance," Townsend said.
The upgrade does not just reflect the underperformance, he said, because "as we look at the group today, it's with a focus on whether the fundamentals are in place (for a rally)."
Townsend declined to make a prediction about the broader market, but said "it's hard to be too optimistic in technology if the broader market seems vulnerable to a correction."

The American Stock Exchange's computer technology index rose seven points, or 2.5 percent, to 279.29. On a percentage basis, the index's gains were triple the Dow's 48 point, 0.83 percent, rise to 5819.
Townsend's technology call brings his short-term rating in line with his long-term weighting, which has remained at overweight for some time, he said.

Technology stocks topped the actives lists on both the NSYE and Nasdaq, where Oracle Corp was most active, rising 3-3/8 to 40-7/8 after Alex Brown upgraded the shares to buy and Cowen & Co reiterated its strong buy rating.
Intel Corp rose 2-3/8 to 87-3/4 and modem maker U.S. Robotics Corp rose 4-1/4 to 66. Cisco Systems gained 1-9/16 to 57-3/4 and Microsoft Corp rose 1-1/4 to 129-7/8.
IBM was the NSYE's most active issue, with Micron Technology Inc also busy, rising 1/4 to 23-3/4.
The optimism was not enough for some individual stocks to shake off their troubles. One example was Novell Inc, which fell 1/8 to 10-3/8, after touching a year-low 10-1/8 early in the session.
